title: Authors and Citation
text: Carlisle Rainey. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Rainey C (2023). crdata: Data sets used Carlisle Rainey. https://www.carlislerainey.com/crdata/, https://github.com/carlislerainey/crdata/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {crdata: Data sets used by Carlisle Rainey},   author = {Carlisle Rainey},   year = {2023},   note = {https://www.carlislerainey.com/crdata/, https://github.com/carlislerainey/crdata/}, }

title: crdata R data package
text: goal {crdata} provide easy access data ’ve used research teaching, documentation.

title: crdata R data package
text: ’s minimal example illustrate recommended use.
code: # install package (once per computer) # remotes::install_github("carlislerainey/crdata")  # load data (once per session) weis <- crdata::weisiger2014  # open documentation (as needed) ?crdata::weisiger2014

title: crdata R data package
text: install development version GitHub use: plans moment upload CRAN.
code: # install latest crdata package from github # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("carlislerainey/crdata")

title: crdata R data package
text: three ways access data. ’ll illustrate syntax weisiger2014 data set. Recommended: First, can use weis <- crdata::weisiger2014. prefer approach mirrors weis <- read_csv(path) closely. Second, can refer data set :: operators without creating object. Anytime want use weisiger2014 data set, simply use crdata::weisiger2014. Third, can run library(crdata), lazily loads data sets, weisiger2014 (others) available without crdata:: prefix. see documentation, run ?crdata::weisiger2014.

title: crdata R data package
text: example, McCaskey Rainey (2021) uses data Weisiger (2014) illustrate Firth’s logit using binary outcome small samples. ’s comparison logit models fit using maximum likelihood Firth’s penalized maximum likelihood.
code: # load packages library(tidyverse)  # load data weis <- crdata::weisiger2014  # rescale weisiger2014 explanatory variables using arm::rescale() rs_weis <- weis %>%   mutate(across(polity_conq:coord, arm::rescale))   # fit models f <- resist ~ polity_conq + lndist + terrain + soldperterr + gdppc2 + coord ls <- lm(f, data = rs_weis) # lpm (replicates Table 2 Model 3 of Weisiger 2014) mle <- glm(f, data = rs_weis, family = "binomial") # logistic regression pmle <- glm(f, data = rs_weis, family = "binomial", method = brglm2::brglmFit) # logistic regression   # plot coefficients modelsummary::modelplot(list("Logit via MLE" = mle,                               "Logit via Firth's PMLE" = pmle),                          conf_level = 0.90)

title: crdata R data package
text: Please cite authors original data (data set article)! appropriate references papers data sets given help file data set (e.g., ?crdata::weisiger2014).

what: A data set on nuclear weapons and war; illustrates logistic regression with separation in a large sample — bm2015
title: A data set on nuclear weapons and war; illustrates logistic regression with separation in a large sample — bm2015
text: Bell Miller (2015) data set used Rainey (2016) Rainey (2023) illustrate logistic regression models separation. data reproduce "Firth logit" results "Kargil excluded" throughout Bell Miller (2015). See "Firth logit" column Table B online appendix.

title: A data set on nuclear weapons and war; illustrates logistic regression with separation in a large sample — bm2015
A data set on nuclear weapons and war; illustrates logistic regression with separation in a large sample — bm2015
text: data frame 455,619 observations 14 variables: year year observation (.e., dyad-year) statea numeric COW code first state dyad stateb numeric COW code second state dyad warl2 whether war occurred onenukedyad whether exactly one state nuclear weapons twonukedyad whether states nuclear weapons logCapabilityRatio natural log capability ratio, measures distribution power two states Ally whether two states formal alliance nonaggression pact SmlDemocracy smaller two Polity scores dyad SmlDependence measures economic interdependence; smaller country's imports exports partner divided GDP logDistance natural log distance capitals two states, large states, distance nearest ports Contiguity whether two states continguous MajorPower whether least one states major power NIGOs measures shared membership intergovernmental organizations details, see Rauchhaus (2009, pp. 266-268) Pevehouse Russett (2006, pp. 980-983).

title: A data set on nuclear weapons and war; illustrates logistic regression with separation in a large sample — bm2015
text: Bell, Mark S., Nicholas L. Miller. 2013. "Questioning Effect Nuclear Weapons Conflict." Journal Conflict Resolution 59(1): 74–92. doi:10.1177/0022002713499718 . Pevehouse, Jon, Bruce Russett. 2006. "Democratic International Governmental Organizations Promote Peace." International Organization 60(4): 969-1000. doi:10.1017/S0020818306060322 . Rainey, Carlisle. 2016. "Dealing Separation Logistic Regression Models." Political Analysis 24(3): 339-355. doi:10.1093/pan/mpw014 . Rainey, Carlisle. 2023. "Hypothesis Tests Separation." Forthcoming Political Analysis. doi:10.31235/osf.io/bmvnu . Rainey, Carlisle. 2016. "priors--separation.zip" Replication Data : Dealing Separation Logistic Regression Models. Harvard Dataverse, V1. doi:10.7910/DVN/VW7G2Q/MTJB9H . Rauchhaus, Robert. 2009. "Evaluating Nuclear Peace Hypothesis." Journal Conflict Resolution 53(2): 258–77. doi:10.1177/0022002708330387 .

title: A data set on nuclear weapons and war; illustrates logistic regression with separation in a large sample — bm2015
code: # a simple example  bm <- crdata::bm2015  # formula to reproduce "Firth logit" column of Table B of Bell and Miller's online appendix. f <- warl2 ~ onenukedyad + twonukedyad + logCapabilityRatio +   Ally + SmlDemocracy + SmlDependence + logDistance +   Contiguity + MajorPower + NIGOs  # twonukedyad == 1 perfectly predicts warl2 == 0 table("warl2" = bm$warl2, "twonukedyad" = bm$twonukedyad) #>      twonukedyad #> warl2      0      1 #>     0 454752    805 #>     1     62      0  # logit model with separation fit <- glm(f, data = bm, family = binomial) #> Warning: glm.fit: fitted probabilities numerically 0 or 1 occurred  # Rainey (2023) shows that Wald tests can never reject null when variables #   create separation summary(fit) #>  #> Call: #> glm(formula = f, family = binomial, data = bm) #>  #> Coefficients: #>                      Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)     #> (Intercept)          -3.84661    1.12637  -3.415 0.000638 *** #> onenukedyad           0.91097    0.36852   2.472 0.013437 *   #> twonukedyad         -13.28422  522.98501  -0.025 0.979735     #> logCapabilityRatio   -0.64855    0.12393  -5.233 1.66e-07 *** #> Ally                 -0.44117    0.35226  -1.252 0.210417     #> SmlDemocracy         -0.07472    0.03182  -2.348 0.018860 *   #> SmlDependence      -119.85637   48.96674  -2.448 0.014377 *   #> logDistance          -0.68642    0.13235  -5.186 2.15e-07 *** #> Contiguity            2.94974    0.38336   7.694 1.42e-14 *** #> MajorPower            2.35680    0.39472   5.971 2.36e-09 *** #> NIGOs                -0.02978    0.01181  -2.521 0.011706 *   #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) #>  #>     Null deviance: 1227.87  on 455618  degrees of freedom #> Residual deviance:  909.72  on 455608  degrees of freedom #> AIC: 931.72 #>  #> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 19 #>   # Rainey (2023) shows that the LR test works fine when variables create #   separation, though. fit0 <- update(fit, . ~ . - twonukedyad) #> Warning: glm.fit: fitted probabilities numerically 0 or 1 occurred anova(fit0, fit, test = "Chisq") #> Analysis of Deviance Table #>  #> Model 1: warl2 ~ onenukedyad + logCapabilityRatio + Ally + SmlDemocracy +  #>     SmlDependence + logDistance + Contiguity + MajorPower + NIGOs #> Model 2: warl2 ~ onenukedyad + twonukedyad + logCapabilityRatio + Ally +  #>     SmlDemocracy + SmlDependence + logDistance + Contiguity +  #>     MajorPower + NIGOs #>   Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi) #> 1    455609     911.20                      #> 2    455608     909.72  1    1.475   0.2246

what: A data set on governors' opposition to Medicaid expansion under the ACA; illustrates logistic regression with separation in small samples — br2014
title: A data set on governors' opposition to Medicaid expansion under the ACA; illustrates logistic regression with separation in small samples — br2014
text: data set containing rescaled variables Barrilleaux Rainey (2014) use main statistical model governors' decisions oppose Medicaid expansion Affordable Care Act. importantly, Democratic governors opposed expansion, leading problem separation. Numeric variables rescaled mean 0 SD 0.5; binary variables rescaled mean 0. data set used Figure 2 p. 446 Barrilleaux Rainey (2014).

title: A data set on governors' opposition to Medicaid expansion under the ACA; illustrates logistic regression with separation in small samples — br2014
A data set on governors' opposition to Medicaid expansion under the ACA; illustrates logistic regression with separation in small samples — br2014
text: data frame 50 observations rescaled versions following 10 variables: state name state oppose_expansion equals one state's governor opposed expansion zero otherwise; outcome variable, rescaled gop_governor equals one state's governor Republican zero otherwise percent_favorable_aca estimate percent state's population views ACA favorably gop_leg equals one Republicans control houses state legislature zero otherwise percent_uninsured percent state's population without health insurance bal2012 state's year-end reserves percentage total spending 2012 multiplier state's current Medicaid multiplier percent_nonwhite percent state non-white percent_metro percent state resides metropolitan area details, see Barrilleaux Rainey (2014, pp. 444-445).

title: A data set on governors' opposition to Medicaid expansion under the ACA; illustrates logistic regression with separation in small samples — br2014
text: Barrilleaux, Charles, Carlisle Rainey. 2014. "Politics Need: Examining Governors' Decisions Oppose 'Obamacare' Medicaid Expansion." State Politics Policy Quarterly 14(4): 437–60. doi:10.1177/1532440014561644 . Barrilleaux, Charles, Carlisle Rainey. 2014. "politics_and_need_rescale.csv." Replication data : "Politics Need: Examining Governors’ Decisions Oppose ‘Obamacare’ Medicaid Expansion". UNC Dataverse, V1.  doi:10.15139/S3/12130 . Rainey, Carlisle. 2016. "Dealing Separation Logistic Regression Models." Political Analysis 24(3): 339-355. doi:10.1093/pan/mpw014 . Rainey, Carlisle. 2023. "Hypothesis Tests Separation." Forthcoming Political Analysis. doi:10.31235/osf.io/bmvnu .

title: A data set on governors' opposition to Medicaid expansion under the ACA; illustrates logistic regression with separation in small samples — br2014
code: # a simple example  br <- crdata::br2014  # formula to reproduce Figure 2 on p. 446 of Barrilleaux and Rainey (2014). f <- oppose_expansion ~ gop_governor +  percent_favorable_aca +  gop_leg +  percent_uninsured + bal2012 + multiplier + percent_nonwhite + percent_metro  # gop_governor == 0 perfectly predicts oppose_expansion == 0 table("oppose_expansion" = br$oppose_expansion,       "gop_governor" = br$gop_governor) #>                 gop_governor #> oppose_expansion -0.6 0.4 #>                0   20  14 #>                1    0  16  # logit model with separation fit <- glm(f, data = br, family = binomial)  # Rainey (2023) shows that Wald tests can never reject null when variables #   create separation summary(fit) #>  #> Call: #> glm(formula = f, family = binomial, data = br) #>  #> Coefficients: #>                         Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) #> (Intercept)             -8.85514 1289.76013  -0.007    0.995 #> gop_governor            20.34924 3224.39979   0.006    0.995 #> percent_favorable_aca    0.12755    1.54920   0.082    0.934 #> gop_leg                  2.42938    1.47965   1.642    0.101 #> percent_uninsured        0.92303    2.23424   0.413    0.680 #> bal2012                 -0.05353    0.85353  -0.063    0.950 #> multiplier              -0.35474    1.19260  -0.297    0.766 #> percent_nonwhite         1.43356    2.61588   0.548    0.584 #> percent_metro           -2.75893    1.68666  -1.636    0.102 #>  #> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) #>  #>     Null deviance: 62.687  on 49  degrees of freedom #> Residual deviance: 31.710  on 41  degrees of freedom #> AIC: 49.71 #>  #> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 19 #>   # Rainey (2023) shows that the LR test works fine when variables create #   separation, though. fit0 <- update(fit, . ~ . - gop_governor) anova(fit0, fit, test = "Chisq") #> Analysis of Deviance Table #>  #> Model 1: oppose_expansion ~ percent_favorable_aca + gop_leg + percent_uninsured +  #>     bal2012 + multiplier + percent_nonwhite + percent_metro #> Model 2: oppose_expansion ~ gop_governor + percent_favorable_aca + gop_leg +  #>     percent_uninsured + bal2012 + multiplier + percent_nonwhite +  #>     percent_metro #>   Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi)    #> 1        42     40.551                         #> 2        41     31.710  1   8.8407 0.002946 ** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1

what: A data set on electoral institutions and the number of political parties; illustrates negligible effects (or equivalence tests) and non-normal residuals — cg2006
title: A data set on electoral institutions and the number of political parties; illustrates negligible effects (or equivalence tests) and non-normal residuals — cg2006
text: data set reproduce Clark Golder's "Established Democracies 1946-2000" model Table 2 p. 698. use data example arguing negligible effect equivalence testing (Rainey 2014) example regression models non-normal errors (Baissa Rainey 2018).

title: A data set on electoral institutions and the number of political parties; illustrates negligible effects (or equivalence tests) and non-normal residuals — cg2006
A data set on electoral institutions and the number of political parties; illustrates negligible effects (or equivalence tests) and non-normal residuals — cg2006
text: data frame 50 observations rescaled versions following 10 variables: country name country held election year year election average_magnitude average district magnitude (number seats available district) across districts country enep measure effective number political parties system. Calculated \(ENEP_j = \dfrac{1}{\sum_{= 1}^n v_{ij}^2}\), \(ENEP_j\) represents effective number electoral parties election \(j\) \(v_{ij}\) represents vote share (proportion) party \(\) election \(j\). particular variable effective number electoral parties "" category "corrected" using least component method bounds suggested Taagepera (1997). eneg measure effective number ethnic groups system. Calculated analogously ENEP. upper_tier percentage legislative seats allocated electoral districts lowest electoral tier. en_pres measure effective number presidential candidates. Calculated analogously ENEP. proximity measure temporal proximity presidential legislative elections. Calculated \(2 \times \lvert \frac{L_t - P_{t - 1}}{P_{t + 1} - P_{t - 1}} - 0.5\rvert\), \(L_t\) year legislative election, \(P_{t–1}\) year previous presidential election, \(P_{t+1}\) year next presidential election.

title: A data set on electoral institutions and the number of political parties; illustrates negligible effects (or equivalence tests) and non-normal residuals — cg2006
text: Baissa, Daniel K., Carlisle Rainey. 2018. "BLUE Best: Non-Normal Errors Linear Model." Political Science Research Methods 8(1): 136–48. doi:10.1017/psrm.2018.34 . Clark, William Roberts, Matt Golder. 2006. "Rehabilitating Duverger’s Theory." Comparative Political Studies 39(6): 679–708. doi:10.1177/0010414005278420 . Clark, William Matt Golder. 2007. "Legislative_new.tab." Replication data : Rehabilitating Duverger's Theory: Testing Mechanical Strategic Modifying Effects Electoral Laws. doi:10.7910/DVN/HGXPHP/SVLIF1 . Harvard Dataverse, V1. Rainey, Carlisle. 2014. "Arguing Negligible Effect." American Journal Political Science 58(4): 1083–91. doi:10.1111/ajps.12102 . Rainey, Carlisle. 2013. "cg.csv." Replication data : Arguing Negligible Effect. Harvard Dataverse, V2. doi:10.7910/DVN/23818/TZW36U .

title: A data set on electoral institutions and the number of political parties; illustrates negligible effects (or equivalence tests) and non-normal residuals — cg2006
code: # a simple example  # load Clark and Golder's data cg <- crdata::cg2006  # reproduce Clark and Golder's 1946-2000 Established Democracies model in Table 2 on p. 698 f <- enep ~ eneg*log(average_magnitude) + eneg*upper_tier + en_pres*proximity fit <- lm(f, data = cg2006) summary(fit) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = f, data = cg2006) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -2.5997 -0.7910 -0.2183  0.4440  7.6906  #>  #> Coefficients: #>                             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)                  2.91571    0.17559  16.605  < 2e-16 *** #> eneg                         0.11160    0.07139   1.563 0.118653     #> log(average_magnitude)       0.07799    0.11587   0.673 0.501240     #> upper_tier                  -0.05655    0.02018  -2.803 0.005276 **  #> en_pres                      0.26385    0.06430   4.103 4.79e-05 *** #> proximity                   -3.09757    0.35236  -8.791  < 2e-16 *** #> eneg:log(average_magnitude)  0.26366    0.06735   3.915 0.000104 *** #> eneg:upper_tier              0.05919    0.01429   4.141 4.08e-05 *** #> en_pres:proximity            0.68317    0.13730   4.976 9.08e-07 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 1.332 on 478 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.3966,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.3865  #> F-statistic: 39.28 on 8 and 478 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16 #>   # QQ-plot of residuals qqnorm(residuals(fit))

what: A data set on enforcement operations; illustrates Poisson regression — holland2015
title: A data set on enforcement operations; illustrates Poisson regression — holland2015
text: Holland (2015) data set used Rainey (2023) illustrate difference "average--simulations" directly transformed quantities interest. data reproduce Model (1) Bogota, Lima, Santiago Holland's Table 2 p. 368. Note coefficients Table 2 standardized exponentiated (Stata's) robust standard errors.

title: A data set on enforcement operations; illustrates Poisson regression — holland2015
A data set on enforcement operations; illustrates Poisson regression — holland2015
text: data frame 89 district-level observations across three cities: city observation's city (Holland performs separate analyses city) district name district (unit observation) operations number enforcement operations conducted per month district (averaged across three months per district) lower share lower-class residents district vendors number unlicensed street vendors (thousands) budget district budget per capita population district population (unclear scale) details, see Holland (2015, p. 364) pp. 3-6 file ajps12125-sup-0001-SupMat.docx available journal website.

title: A data set on enforcement operations; illustrates Poisson regression — holland2015
text: Rainey (2023), focus following hypothesis: "first hypothesis enforcement operations drop fraction poor residents electoral district. district poverty negative significant predictor enforcement, politically decentralized cities [Lima Santiago]. Poverty relationship enforcement politically centralized cities [Bogota] one controls number vendors (p. 362)"

title: A data set on enforcement operations; illustrates Poisson regression — holland2015
text: Holland, Alisha C. 2015. "Distributive Politics Enforcement." American Journal Political Science 59(2): 357–71. doi:10.1111/ajps.12125 . Holland, Alisha. 2014. "Replication data : Distributive Politics Enforcement." Harvard Dataverse, V2. doi:10.7910/DVN/24859 . Rainey, Carlisle. 2023. "Careful Consideration CLARIFY: Simulation-Induced Bias Point Estimates Quantities Interest." Political Science Research Methods. Forthcoming. doi:10.1017/psrm.2023.8 .

title: A data set on enforcement operations; illustrates Poisson regression — holland2015
code: # a simple example  # load data holland <- crdata::holland2015  # table of observations per city table(holland$city) #>  #>   bogota     lima santiago  #>       19       36       34   # formula corresponds to model 1 for each city in holland (2015) table 2 f <- operations ~ lower + vendors + budget + population  # fit poisson regression model for Santiago fit <- glm(f, family = poisson, data = holland, subset = city == "santiago") summary(fit) #>  #> Call: #> glm(formula = f, family = poisson, data = holland, subset = city ==  #>     "santiago") #>  #> Coefficients: #>               Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)     #> (Intercept)  2.6190747  0.5185130   5.051 4.39e-07 *** #> lower       -0.0376151  0.0088506  -4.250 2.14e-05 *** #> vendors     -0.2209762  0.1216055  -1.817   0.0692 .   #> budget      -0.0005983  0.0004912  -1.218   0.2232     #> population   0.0154822  0.0093948   1.648   0.0994 .   #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> (Dispersion parameter for poisson family taken to be 1) #>  #>     Null deviance: 226.08  on 33  degrees of freedom #> Residual deviance: 167.49  on 29  degrees of freedom #> AIC: 226.79 #>  #> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 7 #>

what: A data set on guerrilla resistance; illustrates logistic regression with a small sample — weisiger2014
title: A data set on guerrilla resistance; illustrates logistic regression with a small sample — weisiger2014
text: Weisiger (2014) data set used Rainey McCaskey (2021) illustrate Firth's (1993) penalized maximum likelihood estimator. data reproduce Model 3 Table 2 p. 370.

title: A data set on guerrilla resistance; illustrates logistic regression with a small sample — weisiger2014
A data set on guerrilla resistance; illustrates logistic regression with a small sample — weisiger2014
text: data frame 35 observations seven variables: resist whether conquest followed significant guerrilla resistance polity_conq conqueror’s Polity score lndist intercapital distance, logged terrain percentage conquered country’s territory mountainous soldperterr density occupying force, calculated dividing force size area conquered country gdppc2 gross domestic product (GDP) per capita coord whether pre-conquest political leader country, forms natural leader guerrilla resistance, remained free operate country details, see Weisiger (2014, pp. 365-366).

title: A data set on guerrilla resistance; illustrates logistic regression with a small sample — weisiger2014
text: Firth, David. 1993. "Bias Reduction Maximum Likelihood Estimates." Diometrika 80(1): 27-38. doi:10.1093/biomet/80.1.27 Rainey, Carlisle Kelly McCaskey. 2021. "Estimating Logit Models Small Samples. Political Science Research Methods 9(3): 549-564. doi:10.1017/psrm.2021.9 Weisiger, Alex. 2014. "Victory Without Peace: Conquest, Insurgency, War Termination." Conflict Management Peace Science 31(4): 357–382. doi:10.1177/0738894213508691 Weisiger, Alex. 2014. "conq_ins_data.tab." Replication data : Victory without Peace: Conquest, Insurgency, War Termination., Harvard Dataverse, V1. doi:10.7910/DVN/OPCGOE/Q40MGO

title: A data set on guerrilla resistance; illustrates logistic regression with a small sample — weisiger2014
code: # a simple example  weis <- crdata::weisiger2014  # formula for Model 3 in Table 2 of Weisiger (2014) f <- resist ~ polity_conq + lndist + terrain + soldperterr + gdppc2 + coord  # reproduce Weisiger's LPM estimates ls <- lm(f, data = weis) # linear probability model summary(ls) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = f, data = weis) #>  #> Residuals: #>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max  #> -0.60206 -0.26321  0.01564  0.18910  0.74388  #>  #> Coefficients: #>               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    #> (Intercept) -1.619e+00  6.229e-01  -2.599  0.01475 *  #> polity_conq -2.248e-02  1.350e-02  -1.665  0.10705    #> lndist       2.433e-01  8.257e-02   2.946  0.00642 ** #> terrain      5.191e-03  3.794e-03   1.368  0.18211    #> soldperterr -2.544e-02  3.410e-02  -0.746  0.46195    #> gdppc2      -3.787e-05  4.521e-05  -0.838  0.40938    #> coord        4.365e-01  1.522e-01   2.867  0.00778 ** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 0.3428 on 28 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.6082,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.5242  #> F-statistic: 7.244 on 6 and 28 DF,  p-value: 9.718e-05 #>   # fit a logit model mle <- glm(f, data = weis, family = "binomial") # logistic regression summary(mle) #>  #> Call: #> glm(formula = f, family = "binomial", data = weis) #>  #> Coefficients: #>               Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)   #> (Intercept) -2.820e+01  1.409e+01  -2.001   0.0454 * #> polity_conq -3.442e-01  2.200e-01  -1.565   0.1176   #> lndist       3.539e+00  1.884e+00   1.878   0.0604 . #> terrain      3.385e-02  5.957e-02   0.568   0.5698   #> soldperterr -6.011e-02  3.982e-01  -0.151   0.8800   #> gdppc2      -9.639e-04  1.046e-03  -0.922   0.3566   #> coord        5.648e+00  3.087e+00   1.830   0.0673 . #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) #>  #>     Null deviance: 47.111  on 34  degrees of freedom #> Residual deviance: 15.513  on 28  degrees of freedom #> AIC: 29.513 #>  #> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 7 #>

title: crdata 0.0.0.9000
text: Pre-release version testing.
